PRINCE ALBERT, N. W. T.

THE SCHOOL LAW
There would not appear to have been any
many difficulties in connection with the
establishment of schools in the North.
Districts. In most districts the matter
remained undetermined without any de-
cision having been made by the Govern-
ment. The several religious bodies have
not applied for land and the question of
settlement, the large number of settlers
having been unable to make any progres-
sive advance in distance from the settle-
ments of the Orientals.
With regard to the manner in which the
funds have been applied, it must be con-
sidered that the amount of money involved
is quite small compared to the great
amount of expenditure required. The
question of the manner in which the-
services of the school system are being
maintained, is a matter of serious con-
cern. It appears that the funds are being
used for purposes other than those intended,
and that the services of the school system
are not being maintained in a satisfactory
manner.

NOTICE
The following notification is hereby given:
The Board of Trustees of the District School
District No. 19, Prince Albert, N. W. T., are
asked to meet at the Town Hall on Thursday,
February 26th, at 8 p.m., to consider the
question of the consolidation of two school
districts into one. All persons interested are
invited to attend.

PUBLIC NOTICE.
Bridge at Macfarlane's Creek.
The bridge to be 230 feet long and 12 feet wide, wood sills to be 12 inches and laid on heavy bedding and to be 10 feet wide; the bridge to be 5 strangers in width, with the strangers to be 16 inches at each end and 22 feet long; and of good squared timber, the bridge in the centre post to be 12 inches square, and extended at both ends; also to have double mud sills on each side of the creek 2 feet apart; the hand rails to be 3 inches wide and 1 inch thick; and from 3 to 5 inch face railings, to be extended along the edge of the roadway to 24 feet long; a log to be placed between the side posts, so as to connect the whole length of the bridge.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 29, 1884.
COMMUNICATIONS.

TELEGRAPH QUESTION.

To the Editor of The Times,

I notice in your issue of the 26th last month a peculiarly curious signification from yourself under a signature identical with your own—“Facts,” most strangely inscribed. I have neither the desire nor the ability to quote any extracts of the context in question, but I wonder why you should sign yourself “Facts”? Facts, as indeed they are, are facts, yet not all facts are equally important. Since you have been very careful to sign yourself “Facts,” let me justify my action by saying that I do not believe there can be any gain whatever by publicising the minute details of Government business or in the ordinary routine of everyday life, unless it is clearly of particular interest to the nation at large. Such matters as the Queen’s birthday, the State visits to foreign countries, and other similar events, may certainly be considered as matters of national importance, and it would be quite reasonable to expect that such matters would be made known to the public at large through the medium of the press. However, there is another reason why I feel it necessary to make a statement to the effect that I do not agree with the practice of signing oneself “Facts” on matters of public interest, and I should be glad if others would take note of this fact and follow suit.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

THE NORTH WEST AND ITS CLIMATE.

To what extent the climate of Canada for the summer months offers suitable conditions for the encouragement of emigration? This question has been much discussed recently, and during the past year the opinions expressed have varied widely. It seems to me that the main factors influencing the decision whether or not to emigrate should be the economic benefits which may accrue from the settlement in that country.

The following extract from a report on the Canadian climate states:

"The climate of Canada for the summer months is generally agreeable, and offers many advantages for emigrants. The average temperature is about 70° F., and the humidity is high, with a marked tendency towards the hot moist conditions prevalent in the Southern States. The climate is generally healthy, and the air is clean and pure."

In conclusion, I believe that the decision to emigrate should be based on a consideration of all the facts and not solely on the climate.
